257244675.name: Flyers dancing!
257244675.author: a TripAdvisor user
257244675.reviewBody: Papantla is a small town, I visited in 2008, but to be able to see the Voladores of Papantla live, is such an amazing experience. Their ability to do such thing are incredible! So entertaining, cultural and colorful. It\'s something that you can\'t see in other country in the world.

255524472.name: Flyers!
255524472.author: a TripAdvisor user
255524472.reviewBody: The Voladores of Papantla are known all over the state.  When we were in Tlacotalpan for Dia de Candelaria, the toy pole-and-flyers were being sold up and down the streets.  The Real Voladores, in both Papantla centro and at El Tajin, are brave, colorful and entertaining.  They are also keeping alive a bit of pre-Columbian history for this area.  They deserve the tips they ask for!

253664409.name: Overrated
253664409.author: a TripAdvisor user
253664409.reviewBody: You don\'t need to go to Papantla to see this, as it\'s done right outside the anthropology museum in Mexico City every day. Interesting, I suppose, but not worth a trip to Papantla!

228887276.name: They Are Amazing - !
228887276.author: a TripAdvisor user
228887276.reviewBody: We watched them perform in a grassy area in front of the Museo Nacionale de Anthropologia.  The pole is 100 km in the air.  How one of them can simultaneously \'unwind\' the rope while upside down, play the piccolo-like instrument and tap the drum at the same time is amazing - !  These \'flyers\' are as good as Cirque du Soliel - !

190783867.name: short visit
190783867.author: a TripAdvisor user
190783867.reviewBody: just ok not much to say been there many times it has turned into a tourist trap not anything as it was in the not to distance past but its a must see if you have not been there do it twice the 1st & the last

174046305.name: Spectacular Totonac Ritual
174046305.author: a TripAdvisor user
174046305.reviewBody:
Watching the brightly-clad 'birdmen' swing around and around, gradually unwinding the rope attached to their feet is like nothing else. These men wear red pants and white shirts with a sash around their chests and a brightly colored cap. They stand out against the blue sky. Although some reviewers have said it was a Mayan ritual, the pole-dancers originated with the Nahua (Aztecs from central Mexico), the Otomi (from Hidalgo state) and the Huastecas (San Luis Potosi state). The Totonacs adopted the 'dance' and it is today associated with them. Many years ago, the dancers flew from a metal pole donated by PEMEX, the oil company. Today the pole is also decorated. 

There is no relation to bungee jumping. The men swing around in an ever-increasing arc since their legs are tied to ropes that are wound tightly around a very tall pole. The event is over when they touch the ground standing up. 

The dance is accompanied by Totonacs playing wind flutes. This is not just something put on for tourists (though it is now regularly scheduled). These people are really serious about their ritual. It may have originated to appeal to the gods for rain during a drought. These guys are seriously praying while they practice the exhibition. 

People should be respectful while observing the ceremony. The dancers ask for a donation afterwards, which is only appropriate. Their costumes cost them thousands of pesos  and they need to make a living too.

169207142.name: nice outdoor activity
169207142.author: a TripAdvisor user
169207142.reviewBody: very educational. last ts of shopping. ruins all looked alike. not wheel chair friendly. the flyers are interesting

148753822.name: Birdmen ritual.
148753822.author: a TripAdvisor user
148753822.reviewBody: This was centuries before the bungijump, and it\'s a very interesting mayan ritual boys had to do to prove to his family and community that he was ready to become a man. \n\nIf you have never seen it it\'s really worth your time. You will see that boys had to really be brave to pull this stunt.

142923845.name: Worth seeing this
142923845.author: a TripAdvisor user
142923845.reviewBody: Amazing show by los voladores de Papantla, worth staying to enjoy their performance. Highly recommend this.

142342464.name: Fantastic show
142342464.author: a TripAdvisor user
142342464.reviewBody: Especially if you see it where it all started - in Papantla! If you can\'t - you can see it in many other places, e.g. Xochimilco floating gardens (in Nuevo Nativitas, near the parking lot), Anthropological Museum in Mexico City (in front of the entrance), Tulum (parking lot), sometimes near the Cholula Pyramid

139355959.name: Bird Men
139355959.author: a TripAdvisor user
139355959.reviewBody: I have seen these guys in Mexico City. It really was a unique experience. It\'s incredible what these guys can do - breathtaking. If you get an opportunity to see them - go and see them! It\'s really worth it.

135003327.name: This is ancient Mayan bungee jumping !!!
135003327.author: a TripAdvisor user
135003327.reviewBody: These guys are awsome and as they say, "dont try this at home".!!! Their feet and bodies are tied to the top of  a tall pole about as high as a 7 story building. Then they jump and slowly unravel their ropes while hanging upside down and swinging around the pole until they reach the end of their ropes and land on the ground unharmed !! One guy even stays on top of the pole and plays a Mayan flute. I have seen these guys in both Cancun,(Xcaret) and the ruins of Taijin in Veracruz. Good show, guys !!!

124774368.name: What a (head) rush!
124774368.author: a TripAdvisor user
124774368.reviewBody: A unique ritual and performance. The insistence of paying at least 30 pesos "donation" per person did not sit too well with me. But - oh well ...

124586902.name: Great visit, even in the rain
124586902.author: a TripAdvisor user
124586902.reviewBody: My wife and I live less than two hours\' bus ride from Papantla.  We visited only for a weekend, but plan to return.  The voladores perform every hour daily from 9am to 6pm.  We talked with them and took pictures of course, for a small tip.  They are very friendly.  Their performance is impressive, majestic, and a cultural gem for all of Mexico.  I was surprised that they continued to perform, even in the rain!  However, we found the slight drizzle to be refreshing since for 8 months or so of the year triple digit temps are the norm. . . .  A charming performance and a lovely town.

123601531.name: Extremely interesting, great look at Mexican culture
123601531.author: a TripAdvisor user
123601531.reviewBody: This was really a fabulous glimpse at an ancient Mexican cultural tradition.  I enjoyed watching them very much.  This is basically an aerial dance that takes place atop a tall pole.  The dance starts with very nice flute music as gradually the dancers descend from the pole on ropes while performing a ritual aerial dance.  Truly amazing ... and famous throughout Mexico.  We saw the voladores perform at El Tajin ... they also perform in traditional native costumes which are very unique and interesting.

121459612.name: Lovely little town
121459612.author: a TripAdvisor user
121459612.reviewBody: My friend and I were the only gringos in town.  Charming zocalo, home of the original voladores, amazing sight, good food, amiable people.

119662490.name: Head down flying in prehispanic Mexico
119662490.author: a TripAdvisor user
119662490.reviewBody: This is an old indigenous tradition symbolizing the year ahead. As I am a Skydiver I find it very interesting since the discipline I practice is head down flying or freefly...plus if you know some history of the Mexican people, it adds to your culture.\nIt is a surviving prehispanic tradition.

605807516.name: A must go while in Veracruz just 30min from Port of Veracruz
605807516.author: a TripAdvisor user
605807516.reviewBody: This is the place where all the commercial exchange began when the Spanish were here, this was the first port and the house was the first customs office. There will be kids that will happy explain to you the history of the place and walk you around for a tip (50 - 100 pesos) this is their only way of living and I recommend "hiring" one since they can tell you where are the locals places to eat and hire tours to the virgin beach nearby.

The house itself isnt so spectacular or historical but what is striking is how nature has takeb over the house through a century. It would be nice if this place was developed more into a natural attraction to bring in more visitors. I liked it and my girlfriend loved the place!

address.streetAddress: La Antigua, Ver. Centro Del Poblado

371050249.name: Nothing to write home about
371050249.author: a TripAdvisor user
371050249.reviewBody: If you are in Veracruz you will probably also visit Antigua, the old Vera Cruz. There you can have a look at a building (in ruins) that is said to have been Cort\u00e9s\' house although some people say that he only used it as a storehouse for his goods. But with some imagination you can still see Cort\u00e9s walking around here and then visiting the small chapel towards the river which was the first Spanish chapel on firm American land.

address.streetAddress: La Antigua, Ver. Centro Del Poblado

367538838.name: Fascinating structure and history
367538838.author: a TripAdvisor user
367538838.reviewBody: I was absolutely fascinated by the ruins of this historic house literally held up by the roots of the trees that grew over the house and collapsed the roof.  We did have a private guide that explained all the history to us.  There is not much in the way of explanation if you don\'t have a guide.

address.streetAddress: La Antigua, Ver. Centro Del Poblado

350925516.name: short interesting side trip
350925516.author: a TripAdvisor user
350925516.reviewBody: great place to stop on the way to veracruz headind south about 20 min out .lovely area good rest. & lots of history about cortez .his home needs to be seen to understand the people very friendly its a must see & only 1 k off the main highway . look for a guide they make the visit more interesting

address.streetAddress: La Antigua, Ver. Centro Del Poblado

345047139.name: Not really Hernan Cortes\' house but....
345047139.author: a TripAdvisor user
345047139.reviewBody: This isn\'t Hernan Cortes\' house but it was still pretty cool to see how the trees have grown and "swallowed" much of this property.  I liked it because it\'s old and organic, and even though Hernan never lived there (a woman trying to make money posted a sign saying it was his house so she could collect the entrance fees), it is believed he visited this house hundreds of years ago.  This isn\'t a "must do" in Veracruz, but you\'ll enjoy it.

309659642.reviewBody: Too bad the government or a historic society has lot the opportunity to keep maintain , rebuild, restore such piece of history.  Built in 1518 and some of the walls still standing are being swallowed by the roots of the trees that once kept this home cooled and grandiose.

454113289.reviewBody: I found it to be an average stadium. Architecturally speaking Nothing special about it and it could use a good upgrade. I am a soccer fan but I did not go to the game.

321868358.name: Tiburones Rojos del Veracurz
321868358.author: a TripAdvisor user
321868358.reviewBody: Going to El PIrata Fuente Stadium is like been in a Brazilian stadium, Beautiful people, they cheers  loud for the home team Los Tiburones,  you see the game with the rhythm of batucada, You will have a experience of 2 hours of carnival on your seat, very joyful and fun time with the Jarochos. Now the team is doing very well in the league

299015876.name: Surprisingly nice soccer stadium
299015876.author: a TripAdvisor user
299015876.reviewBody:
A visit to watch the local Los Tiburones soccer team is a fun, safe, and inexpensive activity while in Veracruz.

When we found out that the local soccer team, Los Tiburones, were going to be playing while we were in Veracruz, we knew we had to watch a game. There are two types of games, though we don't remember the names. One apparently is more important because the tickets cost a lot more.

We ended up going to a game with cheaper tickets, around six dollars each for on the field seats. Despite the fact that they seem to be a minor team the fans in attendance were all decked out in the team jerseys, colors (red), and costumes. We also arrived a few minutes after the game started and there was still a longish line to get in.

Once we had our tickets it was somewhat annoying to have to walk all the way to the other side of the stadium to enter. You'd think the ticket windows would be near the entrance, but maybe there is some strategy to this layout, who knows. To enter you have to walk into one of two giant shark mouths. The stadium was far from full but there were enough fans to make it interesting.

We had a few beers and micheladas while there and they were very cheap by U.S. stadium standards, but expensive when compared to what was sold outside the stadium. The stadium itself impressed us with its design and amenities, it looked good.

We felt completely safe the whole time and it seemed like a family atmosphere. The area around the stadium also has a few decent looking places for tacos and beers. In general, the stadium is in a nice part of town and well lit.

613935025.name: Different place to visit in Veracruz
613935025.author: a TripAdvisor user
613935025.reviewBody: Interesting place to know a cocodrile farm, and they conservation of the species efforts. You can choose two tours, the short one of 25 mins length or the long one of 45 mins length.

itemReviewed.name: El Colibri de la Antigua Granja de Cocodrilos

556176299.name: Beautiful Restaurant
556176299.author: a TripAdvisor user
556176299.reviewBody: We have eaten here many times and are sure to return.  We have had various items off the menu and have enjoyed them all.

508252104.name: One of my favorite places in Mexico
508252104.author: a TripAdvisor user
508252104.reviewBody:
It was one of my first places to visit in Mexico and I just felt impressed with the view from the top of the hills on the left side of the beach.
The beach itself is pretty good and I do recommend to visit during the Summer, specially from July to September, where the water is totally blue and you can have a good time :).
There are some hostels and some hotels nearby the beach and at the other side of the entrance do Villa Rica, you can find the entrance to Quiahuiztlán, an archaeological site built by the Totonac civilization, which has a huge archaeological site in the North of Veracruz (157km). 
For me, this place means a lot :). A totally recommend Villa Rica, specially in the summer.

344839917.name: a local beach
344839917.author: a TripAdvisor user
344839917.reviewBody: Playa Villa Rica is very popular with Mexican people. There is lot of opportunities for amusement but for a realy pleasant beach it is better to go a little further to Boca del Rio

277388114.name: love 2 days in ver. mx.
277388114.author: a TripAdvisor user
277388114.reviewBody: this is just one of the finest places i have been everything better than you could expect from the valet parking to paying the bill you fill in the rest just fantastic 10 diamonds !

665302995.name: Magnificent white-water rafting plus zipline and lunch
665302995.author: a TripAdvisor user
665302995.reviewBody: Early April 2019 my family (3 adults, my son, 12) was part of a large private Mexican group with a group reservation. We paid 300 pesos per person (about $ 16 USD, 14 Euro) for: about four hours in an inflatable raft with life vests and helmets, five passengers to a guide, and hot wrapped tamales and corn on the cob at the end, and a ride to the take-in and return to the parking. The guides also let us swim at several magic places, including a magnificent waterfall at the beginning, and those who wanted to, crossed the river on a zipline (safely and professionally aided). The rapids were really demanding and required good paddling and practice, and another boat capsized and all fell in the water, but my other two adults were experienced and prevented our boat from flipping. Sadly, some of our friends in the other boats fell on rocks, when their boat flipped. They wrote only our first names down at the beginning. (I am very happy this is not "America Liability Sue You Nation!", which puts an end to all fun and just pays lawyers and drives up the price...) All of my Mexican friends took it in stride and worked on their bruises later. I was the only non-Mexican lady, (I am German) plus, my family members are not Mexican. I experienced beautiful camaraderie, team spirit, hospitality, gratitude and community. I can very highly recommend this activity to experienced white-water rafters with a sense of adventure, who will accept responsibility for themselves. Along the river, we saw many locals in the water, and cows, other wildlife, rocks, waterfalls. Another river with warmer water merged with the Rio Filolobos. We totally loved this day out in the middle of nowhere off the grid floating down a clean, clear Mexican river. It brings us back to nature (for all those who are glued to social media and screens all the time).

605807105.name: Great for rafting in crystal clear blue waters!
605807105.author: a TripAdvisor user
605807105.reviewBody: I went in a couple road trip to do rafting, we enjoyed so much, the level of the river was 4 (the most dangerous one) it was intrepid and amazing experience, you have to be prepared with helmet and all safety equipment, I recommend hiring a certified tour company to do the activity, besides of the rapids there\'s nothing to do here so come by the morning and return to your base city in the night.

263258337.name: Heavenly valley
263258337.author: a TripAdvisor user
263258337.reviewBody: I hope nothing comes to develop this place or put up the ugly signs so beloved to Mexican sites.  We drove down a bumpy dirt road, across a bridge that was actually a few inches below the surface of the water, and parked among the meandering friendly cattle. We dared to do this because a young man on a motorbike led us down  like someone in a fairy tale, and we paid a small fee (about $3) to bring the car past a gate.  Several people were gearing up to ride rubber boats toward the waterfall hidden by the canyon walls. The two of us had our own boatman/boat, and were ferried up the canyon a short distance. Our man held the boat in place in a bubbling seething pool where the falls landed for as long as we wished, about 15 minutes. The spray was moistening our faces and clothes, but it was light and warm.  We paid a very small per-person amount for this, compared to how fantastic it was.  Afterwards we lay by the side of the river and read.  Do this but keep it a secret.

254780954.name: This review is about the archeological site "El Cuajilote" on Rio Filobobos
254780954.author: a TripAdvisor user
254780954.reviewBody:
The river "Rio Filobobos" is a beautiful natural attraction for wild water and landscape lovers, but I do not know it well enough to discuss it. I will concentrate on the archeological site "El Cuajilote" on the rivers bank. 
Getting there is not trivial, as names are repeated and the river itself is quill long and deep in the mountains. Google maps gives no unique answers but in the town of Tlapacoyan any cab driver knows the place but under the name "filobobos" which also appears on some roadsigns as you approach.
The paved road becomes a dirt road and finally a farm path. There was a gate that was closed but could be opened. Any touristic amenities mentioned in guide books and articles are inexistent!
Yet one can get to the very edge of the site with any car, at least in the dry season! 
The site has very few visitors except between Christmas and new year and during easter week, as I was told by the guards. This allows to visit a rather remarkable with a main plaza with pyramidal platforms arranged in an amazingly beautiful way, and in a gorgeous Jungle setting. 
Yet there is  a nicely tended grass area between the excavated parts so one can easily appreciate the very fie geometrical setting of the main part of the site. I would say it is a very beautiful place and worth a visit for any fan or archeological sites also because the architecture is an interesting amalgamate of Tajin style and Theotihuacan influence.
It is not one of the topflight sites (like theotihuacan, Tajin, Monte Alban or the top Mayan sites,
but has a good place in the next lower league!
Another site, Vega d lea Peña which can be visited nearby after a medium hard walk. The path is not well defined and marked, and we made quite a detour. If you go, remebr that this site is also next to the river. So don't go more then say 50meters above the riverbed.
The site itself is quite unremarkable, but if you want a hike in an amazing setting, it is a good idea to go.

190784211.name: wasted day
190784211.author: a TripAdvisor user
190784211.reviewBody: a long drive & unless your a extremest stay away nothing there except a cow pasture & boat ride everyone trying to take you many different prices dont reccomrend

631751913.name: must see
631751913.author: a TripAdvisor user
631751913.reviewBody: best way to go is to ride the piojo from Malecon, is unexpensive and punctual, Sundays there is no fee, you can hire guides, 1.5 hours enough to visit and take pictures, nice historic place

582721470.name: A must see/do
582721470.author: a TripAdvisor user
582721470.reviewBody: This place is great! Of course I like old forts. This one is way out on the water (not really that far in a taxi though). The old buildings are great to walk through. It actually was a prison for awhile. Would not want to have been there. They have a small museum where maybe the pieces (Olmec I think) are copies because they look sooo good. It probably gives a good idea of what the artifacts were like when they were made. Really a small but mighty museum. A must see place in Veracruz.

address.streetAddress: Camino Escénico a San Juan de Ulúa S/N

539240516.name: Fascinating.
539240516.author: a TripAdvisor user
539240516.reviewBody: San Juan de Ullua has a long and fascinating history, explained clearly by our excellent guide Joel Castelan. A must see when in Veracruz.

514480005.name: mx. history
514480005.author: a TripAdvisor user
514480005.reviewBody: its very interesting what happened here & why it was necessary you will spend several hours if you want to take it all in well worth the visit

500330077.author: a TripAdvisor user
500330077.reviewBody: Worth a trip across the port to see this historical site.   I was fortunate and got an English guide- but even if self guided, it\'s worth seeing!

496020209.name: Historic

487319778.name: paradise 2.5 hrs south of veracruz
487319778.author: a TripAdvisor user
487319778.reviewBody: Drive to Catemaco, stay the night then short drive to Sontecomapan. Hire a Launch to take you and your family  through the last of the Mangrove swamps which is still living and available in the state of Veracruz. The Launch then takes you on a tour to Barra de Sontecomapan. Swim in the sea or the Lagoon. EAt some frsh fish and have a really good day. The kids will definately sleep on the way back to Catemaco.\nDOnt forget the Sunscreen and botteled water.

202066888.name: Heaven of peace
202066888.author: a TripAdvisor user
202066888.reviewBody: The laguna de Sontecomapan is a fantastic place if you are looking for a heaven of peace and silence. The big lake and river enters in the Gulf of Mexico at La Barra. A recommended place to stay is Rancho los Amigos, right on the shore of the lagoon and just 3 minutes before arriving at La Barra. Check their web site Losamigos.com.mx and the latest reviews in Trip Advisor. There you can appreciate the wild nature (plenty of birds, parrots, hummingbirds) but most of all the silence of the nature. You can take long walks around the hacienda and the surrounding hills, or kayak or swim around the lagoon.

169676734.name: What a great boat trip
169676734.author: a TripAdvisor user
169676734.reviewBody: we go at least 2 times a year on this Laguna. Great views of the Los Tuxtlas mountains. All the different shades of greens behind a blue sky is incredible. \n

631755263.name: night street dancing
631755263.author: a TripAdvisor user
631755263.reviewBody: you can walk day or night but by night you can see folkloric dancing like jarochos, danzon coupled and sometime even contests like I was able to watch on Saturday afternoon with dozens of kids

585108140.name: very very cool, live dancing, with live band
585108140.author: a TripAdvisor user
585108140.reviewBody: How could it get any better than a live 40 piece band, live dancers, just normal folks dancing and enjoying life, old couples were prevalent, and all dress up and danced their hearts out, open to all

582723306.name: Very cool
582723306.author: a TripAdvisor user
582723306.reviewBody: I love plazas. Especially the main ones in a big old city. And this one has it all. Most nights there are festivities with music and dancing. Lots of restaurants surround on a couple of sides and music is always playing in the streets at normal hours. Very pretty. The Palacio and Cathedral are on the plaza. A short walk to the Malecon.

554302464.name: Fascinating from various vantage points
554302464.author: a TripAdvisor user
554302464.reviewBody: What I like about this Plaza de Armas is that a real public space used and enjoyed by the Veracruz community, which happens to also welcome visitors -- who can absorb a better sense of the community by walking around, stopping at a government building, at the cathedral, or at any of the restaurants/coffee shops facing the plaza. It\'s also great to look down upon it from several of the bordering hotels, the Colonial, say, or the Gran Hotel Diligencias. My favorite time is at nightfall when there are often beautiful performances of \'danz\u00f3n\', music and dance.

497692226.name: Lively
497692226.author: a TripAdvisor user
497692226.reviewBody: Visited the "Zocalo" every day during our two week stay in Veracruz. It\'s always lively and there seems to be a special event every evening. The plaza is surrounded by a church, hotels, restaurants, stores, and a municipal palace. If you enjoy people watching, this is a great spot. There are shoe-shiners, vendors, street-people, policemen, old people, young people, couples,  lovers,  children, office workers, students, tourists  and more to see.

484973087.name: Lovely Colonial Central Square
484973087.author: a TripAdvisor user
484973087.reviewBody: We really enjoyed a three day visit to Veracruz. The central square, the Plaza De Armas is where we tended to gravitate towards every evening as there are some gorgeous restaurants and bars both on it and around it and the place has a lovely vibe.\nBy day it is still well worth a visit too as the arcades and facades are beautifully ornate. Definitely our favourite part of the city.

453160547.name: Beatifull place
453160547.author: a TripAdvisor user
453160547.reviewBody: Nice and cultural place to go and chillin\'. Very near to La Plaza de Tecnolog\u00edas with electronic products with low prices. Some pubs and restaurants around.

358997701.name: Always full
358997701.author: a TripAdvisor user
358997701.reviewBody:
Always full of people and with shows.

Lots of live music and people walking bye.  You can eat in the different areas around it.

It was recently burned by a fire so the main palace looks burned.

Nice place to also see the church cathedral of veracruz.

345298960.name: lots of Awesome Archetecture
345298960.author: a TripAdvisor user
345298960.reviewBody:
had a stroll in this area with a few friends and found quite a lot of activity going on. street shows, concerts. dancing. lots of shopping and vendors. and tons of old structural buildings to take snapshots of. 
Be wary the town is a bit dusty and dirty but hey its el mexico. and it wont bother you unless your a major germaphobe, heck almost every city in the states has a unkempt part, no differnce here.
And if your looking for a slice of home there is a Burger King hiding on a second story of a building.. you just have to keep an eye out for it. 
enjoy

344837065.name: the place to be in Veracruz
344837065.author: a TripAdvisor user
344837065.reviewBody: It is the main square of the city with a lot od terraces where you can watch what is going on.In the evening there is a lot of live music

321258722.name: Don\'t go on Sunday
321258722.author: a TripAdvisor user
321258722.reviewBody: I have mixed thoughts about this place because I\'ve been there 3 times, and the first 2 were pretty good; but this last time was very uncomfortable. The streets where dirty and smelled like pee, it was also full of locals that made it very hard to walk around.\nMy guess is that on Sundays the streets are dirty because of the amount of people there over the weekend, plus usually on Sundays people don\'t work and they all tend to go downtown.

319867811.name: Nice Center of Historic District
319867811.author: a TripAdvisor user
319867811.reviewBody: It is nice to walk around and there is often some sort of band playing or some sort of dancing. Why we did not really like was all the people approaching you to try to sell their goods, most of which were cheap Asian imports (sun glasses, Pasmina scarves, and knock-off perfumes and colognes). You have to be careful at the restaurants as the wait staff overcharged us and then took a tip on top of the inflated price!

310563926.name: Zocalo Magic
310563926.author: a TripAdvisor user
310563926.reviewBody: The Plaza de Las Armas  (the zocalo) was the focal center of our two day visit to Veracruz.  Each evening there was music, dancing, and lots of people just enjoying this inviting and engaging town square.  One night (Sat. March 7), there was live band and danzon contest, and on the second night (Sun. March 8) there was a dance performance featuring teenagers performing a traditional veracruzano wedding ceremony.  We also saw a few mariachi bands, and lots of people just relaxing and hanging out under the spotlighted palm trees.

284187206.name: Amazing views
284187206.author: a TripAdvisor user
284187206.reviewBody: There is always something going on many people passing by so if you have your camera there is a lot of possibilities, in the evening also there is music bands near by, check the schedule and enjoy

273769827.name: Keep your eyes open
273769827.author: a TripAdvisor user
273769827.reviewBody: The plaza itself is average, and the bands and dancing interesting.  But, be careful. Someone tried and grab my camera out of my hand here -- in broad daylight (5:00 pm).  After a short struggle, I won....the attacker lost.  No police around.  Please be careful.

258688124.name: Romance
258688124.author: a TripAdvisor user
258688124.reviewBody: Very romantic, watching guys and gals discreetly flirt, boys walking opposite to the gals to make eye contact, beautiful!  listening to the local bands while sipping coffee

257355821.name: Far from the nicest Zocalos, with overpriced and badly serviced restaurants.
257355821.author: a TripAdvisor user
257355821.reviewBody: A bit dirty and dusty for being (a) the Zocalo and (b) the Zocalo of Veracruz. Ate in one of the bars on the Zocalo. Got out of there as quick as we could after mediocre food, awfuly margaritas (these were awful for any country in the world, let alone Mexico) and very very bad service. Forgot this place quickly. There was a live band playing in the square with lots of local people dancing some very impressive salsa which was great fun to watch.

206848797.name: A great spot to grab a bit to eat and see the crowds
206848797.author: a TripAdvisor user
206848797.reviewBody: Plaza de Las Armas, or otherwise known as the Zocolo, is a green retreat from the traffic choked streets of downtown Veracruz. Grab a bite at one of the many eateries ringing the perimeter. Or just grab a seat at one of the public benhes. There is plenty of shade and things to watch. Or get your shoes cleaned from one of the shine guys!

189424492.name: Best at Night
189424492.author: a TripAdvisor user
189424492.reviewBody: The plaza is quite nice with some impressive buildings and sidewalk cafes.  But it is at night when you want to be here for the best reason possible--Danz\u00f3n!  The crowd gathers, the musicians play lively Cuban-inspired music, and the dancers have fun.  Those of us watching have just as much fun!  If you\'ve never seen the film Danz\u00f3n from the early 2000\'s, you should try to find it on DVD or via streaming.  It\'s a wonderful film that celebrates this city and it\'s dancing tradition.  Of course, while at the square in the evening, also watch the families playing with toys they have bought their children, the people eating at the hotels\' sidewalk cafes, etc.  It\'s a magical place that makes people happy like the Riverwalk in San Antonio and other outdoor places that are full of activities and fun.

183835632.name: THE NUMBER ONE HANG OUT SPOT IN VERACRUZ CITY
183835632.author: a TripAdvisor user
183835632.reviewBody: Veracruz city is very historic. The Plaza de Las Armas is the center that embraces this history and attracts thousands of citizens daily. There are many restaurants, bars, or cafes to choice. There is also entertainment happening on weekends.  I consider this the busiest area and one of the places that embodies the culture of Veracruz, Mexico.  This is still the evidence of Spanish colonization\'s  influence on the country of Mexico.  There are also many hotels to choice that will place you in close proximity to Plaza de las Armas.

169678999.name: A great area with good music.
169678999.author: a TripAdvisor user
169678999.reviewBody: When we weekend in Veracruz, this is the area we always stay in. The food is too touristy and pricy, good happy hours and after 11 pm listen for salsa music within the 3 or 4 blocks of the zocalo.

145075167.name: Good fun - even better at night
145075167.author: a TripAdvisor user
145075167.reviewBody:
On our way through Mexico we stopped in Veracruz for two nights. We've already seen the nice Zocalos (Main Squares/Plazas) of Merida and Campeche. So we were looking forward to this one.

And we weren't dissapointed. By size it's a lot smaller than the one in Merida. But it's even busier. There's a bunch of stalls selling food, clothes and souvenirs. In the center it's set like a small park with some trees and a bunch of benches to sit down and relax.

The Plaza is traffic free, so it's very convenient to stroll around. On one side there's the big and nice cathedral. There's lots of wine and dine options around the Zocalo. Too bad that they mostly sell similar food - the typical "mexican" fare for tourists. 
But you don't have to go for the food....just grab a few drinks and enjoy some people-watching. There is always some music played somewhere, mostly Mariachi Bands. 

It's really fun - and it gets even more fun after dark. All the locals head out to the Zocalo to and enjoy their time together. On weekends it's completely packed...but in a fun way. The only thing that's very annoying are the street vendors (the walking ones). About every 30 seconds (no kidding!) somebody shows up trying to sell you something. Kids, grown-ups, elderly people. Some just beg for money. I understand that some rely on that income. But you really not get a break. Of course, a firm "No gracias" is mostly enough....but do that for 2-3 hours! Well, it's just part of Veracruz and besides that the Plaza is great fun. It's the place to be in Veracruz, especially at night.

Wanna know more about my trips? Check my profile where you'll also find my website with more info about my travels.

137017910.name: All the Plazas in Mexico are good  but.....
137017910.author: a TripAdvisor user
137017910.reviewBody: but this one is not up to the usual standard in this country... normally these places are frequented by families and are good fun places.. but this one misses out somewhere.  Actually all of Veracruz is looking down and out.. while the rest of Mexico is now clean and safe, the footpaths and streets here are just not up to standard;  what with dangerous holes on or near the footpaths and crossings;  dirty crapped-out buses spewing their fumes into the atmosphere;  even the so called main arterial roads are in a poor state.    This is our second time to Veracruz.. it is our last.

133893848.name: Always buzzing
133893848.author: a TripAdvisor user
133893848.reviewBody: I\'ve visited Veracruz twice and both times theres always been something going on in the square, live music, dancing, comedians! It really feels like the centre of everything and with it\'s huge palm trees just feels like a world away.

131446791.name: a step back in time,  like europe  in the evening
131446791.author: a TripAdvisor user
131446791.reviewBody: the architecture is stunning, the cafes are lively, the music is authentic, the marimba sound is exotic.  better in the evening than in the day.  tourists and locals come to eat, drink, and just sit.

127087436.name: best on dance evenings
127087436.author: a TripAdvisor user
127087436.reviewBody: also known as the Zocalo on some evenings there is a live band and older locals gather for a dance, we went to watch on a thursday evening

125156756.name: Watch the world go by!
125156756.author: a TripAdvisor user
125156756.reviewBody: A great place to people watch and sip a coffee at a sidewalk cafe

89691108.name: Have a quick look during the day but return at night for possible music
89691108.author: a TripAdvisor user
89691108.reviewBody: As major plazas go this one in the center of Veracruz is not the most attractive. It is surrounded by the usual things, old government building with a tourist office, large cathedral, and hotels and sidewalk restaurants. There are many zocalos in Mexican cities that are nicer looking. However, it is a must in Veracruz to be there in the evening. Every night we were in the city last month there was free entertainment including bands, a singer, a clown, and kids who danced. There was always a nice appreciative crowd too. This is a city that likes to party and enjoys entertainment.

660013416.name: Where the sunset action is
660013416.author: a TripAdvisor user
660013416.reviewBody: Great place for locals and tourists. Live music, dancing, food, safe,lively, within walkimg distance from the main plaza. A place to meet, see and be seen. Great dancing couples from Danzon, to Cumbia and Salsa. You can bring your own liquor and nobody cares. Order delicious food  from the surrounding restaurants at bargain prices and after a couple sets go and rest.

319870884.name: Central point for many of the bus stops
319870884.author: a TripAdvisor user
319870884.reviewBody: This is a cute area with some vendors and some nice photographic opportunities. Do not miss the preserved trolley car! It is a little confusing at first as it is a major circle where most busses go through accessing the Marcado, Zocolo, ADO bus station, Plaza Las Americas and other major points in the city.

548694191.name: Excellent place to really absorb Mexico\'s maritime history
548694191.author: a TripAdvisor user
548694191.reviewBody: Excellent place to really absorb Mexico\'s maritime history, and the history of this amazing city. Along with San Juan de Ulua and the Museo Naval, the Baluarte helps provide some real understanding of how lively history can be!

address.streetAddress: At Fco. Canal between Gomez Farias and 16 de Septiembre

497694149.name: Great photo op!
497694149.author: a TripAdvisor user
497694149.reviewBody: The bulwark seems out-of-place but it was on the waterfront when it was built centuries ago. The site is a short walk from the hotel that we stayed at on the Malecon. It was closed when we visited but we took some great photos of the exterior.

address.streetAddress: At Fco. Canal between Gomez Farias and 16 de Septiembre

345996039.name: Small, nice!
345996039.author: a TripAdvisor user
345996039.reviewBody: We stopped by mainly just to get some pictures of the city but we\'re fortunate to happen in to an exhibit of golden artifacts that\'s had been found by a fisherman and finally seized by the government. The person in charge on site gave us a wonderful explanation of the items, their importance, as well as an excellent description of the baluarte and its history. The permanent articles on display and maps were very interesting.\n\nThe baluarte is barely more than a single room with a wide battlement which gives an excellent view of the city.

address.streetAddress: At Fco. Canal between Gomez Farias and 16 de Septiembre

345995879.name: Surprising
345995879.author: a TripAdvisor user
345995879.reviewBody: I don\'t know if they always do this, but we were the only ones there and so the museum custodian gave us a personalized tour and explained everything to us in great detail. This might not be a good value as it cost about $55 pesos and everything is in Spanish. So if you don\'t understand or can\'t read it you might not get as much out of it. However, the views are amazing, out "guide" was so nice and knowledgable and the rest of the staff were very friendly. Honestly I didn\'t expect to have such a great experience, and it\'s not on the main path, but if you find yourself in the area, you should go!!

address.streetAddress: At Fco. Canal between Gomez Farias and 16 de Septiembre

344837864.name: a former fortress
344837864.author: a TripAdvisor user
344837864.reviewBody: It was an important fortress on the waterfront but now is is surrounded by streets. Actualy it is more a ruin than a fort

address.streetAddress: At Fco. Canal between Gomez Farias and 16 de Septiembre

344337906.name: Free Visiting Historic Site
344337906.author: a TripAdvisor user
344337906.reviewBody: This is located near the port, next to Hotel Baluarte, which is where I stayed at. \n\nThis is a classic piece of Verecruz\'s history. You are allowed to walk in the fort style building, neat place.

address.streetAddress: At Fco. Canal between Gomez Farias and 16 de Septiembre

269418626.name: A Piece of Veracruz\'s History
269418626.author: a TripAdvisor user
269418626.reviewBody: A small buy interesting place to visit. The Baluarte of Santiago was once a security post for coastal protection; right now it works as a museum. A brief but interesting experience.

address.streetAddress: At Fco. Canal between Gomez Farias and 16 de Septiembre

246492765.name: Worth every penny.
246492765.author: a TripAdvisor user
246492765.reviewBody: If you just check out the outside. You can even peep in the window. A solid downtown historical site, wish there were more. If you want, you can pay $4 to see a small pile of melted gold.

address.streetAddress: At Fco. Canal between Gomez Farias and 16 de Septiembre

231898187.name: A backyard landmark
231898187.author: a TripAdvisor user
231898187.reviewBody: The Baluarte de Santiago was originally built to protect the city.  When land was gained to the ocean, the baluarte was left inland.  It operates as a museum and houses "Las Joyas del Pescador" (The Fisherman\'s Jewels) it is a small but beautiful jewelry collection found in the Veracruz shores.  It will take you 30 minutes to browse the site.  Photographs in the interior are not allowed which is disappointing, but you can take pictures outside the building. There is not a coffee shop or restaurant inside, but there are several within walking distance.

address.streetAddress: At Fco. Canal between Gomez Farias and 16 de Septiembre

200034302.name: Icon monument
200034302.author: a TripAdvisor user
200034302.reviewBody: When visiting this monument look around close by Huaca neighborhood with wooden house and many attractions just two blocks from Santiago.

address.streetAddress: At Fco. Canal between Gomez Farias and 16 de Septiembre

183044916.name: WELL-PRESERVED PIECE OF VERACRUZ HISTORY
183044916.author: a TripAdvisor user
183044916.reviewBody: Sitting in practically in middle of a community but close enough to the water to make sense of its existence centuries ago. There are no stairs to entrance, just a steep climb, that could be considered wheelchair access. Just be careful coming from down from the attraction because it is very steep.   It is open from 10am to 4:30pm and the cost is 46 MXN pesos (less than $4).  It is a short and sweet journey through a piece Spanish history in Veracruz.  Depending on where you are staying the a Taxi shouldn\'t be more than 80 MXN ($6). I was able to walk four blocks from my hotel in centro historic.  There are also bus tours you can take for 30 MXN (less than $3) that will show all the major sites including Baluarte Santiago.  Yes it is also important to know that there are no English tour guides at the attraction but with the art of photography and language translation, you will get a good idea what the purpose was for this attraction in the 1600s.

address.streetAddress: At Fco. Canal between Gomez Farias and 16 de Septiembre

157539526.name: I learned something new
157539526.author: a TripAdvisor user
157539526.reviewBody: I had not realized that the pre Hispanic Central American Societies had mastered  copper smelting and produced decorative Jewellery from copper.  The gold on display  was an interesting reminder of  the artisanal skills of pre-Colombian societies.

address.streetAddress: At Fco. Canal between Gomez Farias and 16 de Septiembre

154516791.name: Small but informative
154516791.author: a TripAdvisor user
154516791.reviewBody: This place does not have any English translations, it\'s  a small museum. But it\'s really neat to explore and view the fisherman\'s tresuare.

address.streetAddress: At Fco. Canal between Gomez Farias and 16 de Septiembre

146106602.name: Wonderful piece of history
146106602.author: a TripAdvisor user
146106602.reviewBody: One of the many historical places in this great city.  Very small "fort" and museum, but interesting.  It is free on Sundays for Mexican residents, so my wife and I went on a good day. . .  I DO think 46 pesos per person is a bit much for this small of a place.

address.streetAddress: At Fco. Canal between Gomez Farias and 16 de Septiembre

134152783.name: Very Cool Remnant of the Spanish Renaissance
134152783.author: a TripAdvisor user
134152783.reviewBody: Walled fortress with a drawbridge and cannons in the middle of city that was actually used in the 16th & 17th centuries -  What\'s not to love?

address.streetAddress: At Fco. Canal between Gomez Farias and 16 de Septiembre

124774293.name: Baluarte Santiago - see the outside, don\'t pay for the inside
124774293.author: a TripAdvisor user
124774293.reviewBody: Walk around it, climb up to it, circle the tower, take a few pictures. But 46 pesos to peek inside? That does not compare well to the free access city and naval museums - or the 57 pesos fee for the El Tajin pyramids.

address.streetAddress: At Fco. Canal between Gomez Farias and 16 de Septiembre

123374913.name: The remains of an old Spanish fort of 1500\'s with gold inside !!
123374913.author: a TripAdvisor user
123374913.reviewBody: The little fort is worth the three block walk from the zocalo just to see something of the conquistador era. What is really neat to see are the samples of pre hispanic gold jewelry the Spanish were seeking. The samples are few but totally intriguing as to their history of so long ago. I have visited recently museums in Mexico City , Puebla and Xalapa but found few samples of how the gold was worked so beautifully into jewelry.The information of the fort and gold on display is in Spanish only and the walk around the fort and to view the gold samples in the fort should not take you more than twenty minutes. To view inside will cost you 46 pesos and you must walk up a stone ramp to get in.

address.streetAddress: At Fco. Canal between Gomez Farias and 16 de Septiembre

89531243.name: The only remaining portion of the old city wall that protected Veracruz
89531243.author: a TripAdvisor user
89531243.reviewBody: This bit of fortified wall is an important part of the history of Veracruz. Since it has always been the most important of Mexico\'s seaports the city was protected for years by a wall that extended all the way around the city. This was done to keep this important city safe from warring nations and pirates too. But late in the 19th century the wall was dismantled with one small part left standing which is this bulwark. It does look like some lost old fortress which is exactly what it was. If you visit the city of Campeche near the Yucatan peninsula you get a better idea of what these old walls were like. There is a picture in both the Naval Museum and City Museum of Veracruz that shows the city before the wall was brought down and you can therefore see that the wall completly encircled the city. The bit of wall that is the Baluarte Santiago today stands alone in the middle of an otherwise empty block of the city. It is a tourist attraction with a small museum inside. We walked around the perimeter of the bit of wall but did not go inside since the museum had nothing to do with the old bulwark itselt so we were only there for a few minutes.

address.streetAddress: At Fco. Canal between Gomez Farias and 16 de Septiembre

85369325.name: This well maintained old fort is a great reminder of the military struggles which occurred here so many years ago.
85369325.author: a TripAdvisor user
85369325.reviewBody:
This fort, complete with canons, is within walking distance of the main plaza in the city of Veracruz. It was once one of the forts which made up the huge exterior wall surrounding this port city to ward off invasions from other countries and from pirates. The word "Baluarte" actually means fortification or defensive wall. 

It is an interesting place to visit and take photos. The little museum inside the fort does not really have anything to do with the history of the fort but just houses pieces of interesting pre-Columbian jewelry (entrance fee required). To really find out more historical information about this fort, I would recommend going to the nearby Museo Naval (Navy Museum). It is there you can find visual images of how this fort was a part of this once walled city. 

There is no cost to go up into the fort and walk around. However, all museums in Veracruz are closed on Mondays, including Baluarte de Santiago.

address.streetAddress: At Fco. Canal between Gomez Farias and 16 de Septiembre

618341318.name: Accoustics
618341318.author: a TripAdvisor user
618341318.reviewBody: I attended Mass in this sparkling clean and well-lit lovely little church one afternoon. The accoustics were so good that i was able to both hear and understand the sermon - about narcotraficantes - perfectly, a first for me and my self-taught Spanish!

582722426.name: getting there is half the fun
582722426.author: a TripAdvisor user
582722426.reviewBody: I think the church itself has been redone several times. Still, it is in the area where Cortez made the first city of Veracruz and his house is practically next door. You cross the river on a long walking bridge. It is very solid. And it is the oldest Catholic Church in the Americas. The pueblo is very clean and the people/vendors very friendly. Had a young boy as a guide through the ruins of Cortez\'s house. A language barrier...sure...who cares?

418997181.name: Tiny church near Cortes home.
418997181.author: a TripAdvisor user
418997181.reviewBody: A couple of blocks from Cortes home. First church built in Veracruz. Very small and not a lot to see inside.

367630769.name: Historically significant, still standing and in use
367630769.author: a TripAdvisor user
367630769.reviewBody: This is a special and lovely little church with good views of the original material.  A very significant cultural icon representing a huge cultural shift.  The setting is beautiful as well.

351117932.name: Historic Little Church
351117932.author: a TripAdvisor user
351117932.reviewBody: This is the site of the first catholic church built in the Americas, hence it deserves being a landmark.  La Antigua itself was historic in that it was the place where Hernan Cortes had built the first military headquarters in Mexico.

343158716.name: Fantastic place
343158716.author: a TripAdvisor user
343158716.reviewBody: This place is very old. The walls are built with bricks and coral blocks. Definitely one place to visit.

309660101.name: Standing and operational
309660101.author: a TripAdvisor user
309660101.reviewBody: Another piece of the puzzle of the Cortez Conquest of Mexico. This small chapel is still standing and operational, with well preserved furniture and religious artifacts.

259761449.name: Historical value
259761449.author: a TripAdvisor user
259761449.reviewBody: This chapel is very worth seeing. Specially if you include it on a trip to Antigua. This beautiful chapel was the first one in Latin America inland. The chapel has the Catholic stations at the atrium.\nComplement your visit with the first House of Cortes and the hanging bridge. Around it you can also have lunch.

674408010.name: Caminata, ejercicio o comida
674408010.author: a TripAdvisor user
674408010.reviewBody: Este paseo ubicado sobre el Boulevard Vicente Fox tiene el atractivo de ser usado todos los d\u00edas en horas tempranas para correr o caminar. Posee en horas m\u00e1s adelante palapas con comidas t\u00edpicas del mar, refrescos y cervezas. Es una zona segura pero en fin de semana la cantidad de gente y falta de estacionamiento, puede volverlo una pesadilla.

address.streetAddress: Boulevard Manuel Avila Camacho Costa de Oro

645795180.name: Playa junto a Foro Boca
645795180.author: a TripAdvisor user
645795180.reviewBody: una playa muy limpia y tranquila para disfrutar, te rentan las palapas o ya sea que consumas ah\u00ed, s\u00f3lo hay que tener cuidado con una corriente de agua que te jala,pero hay guardavidas todo el tiempo cuidando.

address.streetAddress: Boulevard Manuel Avila Camacho Costa de Oro

622419043.name: Excelente paseo con vista al mar
622419043.author: a TripAdvisor user
622419043.reviewBody: El Foro Boca est\u00e1 excelente, escuchar conciertos, biblioteca y una atractiva cafeter\u00eda !!\nUna combinaci\u00f3n cultural y con la naturaleza... terraza para tomar una bebida.

address.streetAddress: Boulevard Manuel Avila Camacho Costa de Oro

621987891.name: Excelente centro cultural
621987891.author: a TripAdvisor user
621987891.reviewBody: Es un magn\u00edfico lugar para conciertos, lecturas, entretenimiento cultural, es magn\u00edfico que muchos de los eventos sean gratuitos y de mucha calidad.  Las instalaciones de lo mejor. Tienen que visitarlo.

address.streetAddress: Boulevard Manuel Avila Camacho Costa de Oro

618039774.name: Modernidad
618039774.author: a TripAdvisor user
618039774.reviewBody: Futurista, proyecta un Puerto contempor\u00e1neo y de buen gusto, familiar y fres\u00f3n, para gusto refinado.

address.streetAddress: Boulevard Manuel Avila Camacho Costa de Oro

608234494.name: Excelente zona para una buena estancia
608234494.author: a TripAdvisor user
608234494.reviewBody: Si visitas el puerto de Veracruz te recomiendo que revises todos los lugares con que cuenta Boca Del Rio,Veracruz ya que podr\u00e1s encontrar excelentes hoteles, buenos restaurantes, divertidas plazas comerciales, pero m\u00e1s nuevas que en el puerto de Veracruz,  y muy cerca del mismo

address.streetAddress: Boulevard Manuel Avila Camacho Costa de Oro

601410391.name: Distrito Boca
601410391.author: a TripAdvisor user
601410391.reviewBody: Excelente lugar para visitar, se puede practicar el patinaje por todo el malec\u00f3n, pasear a las mascotas o rentar una bicicleta.

address.streetAddress: Boulevard Manuel Avila Camacho Costa de Oro

584883615.name: Vale la pena en la noche
584883615.author: a TripAdvisor user
584883615.reviewBody:
Hay varias Placitas (con ambulantes en la orilla del malecón) en la zona de Boca, una que tiene renta de patines, de bicicletas, varios puestos de raspados y hasta unos helados italianos.
En la noche todo funciona hasta las 11 de la noche!!!
Y ver el atardecer ahí es muy bonito

Para ir en familia

address.streetAddress: Boulevard Manuel Avila Camacho Costa de Oro

638984738.name: ENTERTAINMENT IN VERACRUZ
638984738.author: a TripAdvisor user
638984738.reviewBody: Visiting Veracruz, one focuses on the beach and the landscapes, but at night there is this great place that is very well located in one of the areas with the highest added value in the city. The first thing you will find is a friendly staff willing to help and guide you, an incredible assortment of slot machines and tables with different game modes.\nThe place is very beautiful and the food is pretty good.\nVery fun to have a nice time with friends

254576940.name: Increible lugar para pasarla bien
254576940.author: a TripAdvisor user
254576940.reviewBody: Si te gusta ver los espect\u00e1culo de Aves y reptiles del mundo, excelente para pasarla con la familia y sobre todo los ni\u00f1os, muy recomendable, no dejen de visitarlo.

156888720.name: Crees haber visto todo?
156888720.author: a TripAdvisor user
156888720.reviewBody: Increible lugar, es peque\u00f1o pero todo lo que tienen esta de lujo, esos insectos no se ven en cualquier lugar, felicidades al creador del proyecto.

653530107.name: playa tradicional
653530107.author: a TripAdvisor user
653530107.reviewBody: Es tal vez de las playas emblem\u00e1ticas de veracruz ubicada sobre el bulevar de veraracruz, ha formado parte de la historia de el puerto ya que a\u00f1os atras fue escenario de eventos musicales

address.streetAddress: Boulevard Manuel Avila Camacho Ignacio Zaragoza 2431

584591861.name: Sympa
584591861.author: a TripAdvisor user
584591861.reviewBody: Attention vous \u00eates sur l\u2019Atlantique donc la mer n\u2019est pas vraiment tranquille ! De plus attention aux tiburon

address.streetAddress: Boulevard Manuel Avila Camacho Ignacio Zaragoza 2431

580665637.name: Aceptable pero se puede mejorar
580665637.author: a TripAdvisor user
580665637.reviewBody: Si bien esta playa no es la m\u00e1s limpia que he visitado, si es una playa tranquila, familiar, de oleaje tranquilo y con una gran oferta de "botana" para pasar un rato agradable. Otro plus es su cercan\u00eda a la zona hotelera del puerto y al centro de Veracruz.

address.streetAddress: Boulevard Manuel Avila Camacho Ignacio Zaragoza 2431

541357605.name: Para pasrla bien
541357605.author: a TripAdvisor user
541357605.reviewBody: Esta playa esta cerca de varios hoteles, esta bien en general pero ser\u00eda mejor si hubiera lockers, ba\u00f1os y botes para la basura

address.streetAddress: Boulevard Manuel Avila Camacho Ignacio Zaragoza 2431

507975014.name: Deben cuidar mas las playas
507975014.author: a TripAdvisor user
507975014.reviewBody: Es un lugar bueno para pasar con la familia, sin embargo, deben dar limpieza a las playas.\nEl ambiente es bueno

address.streetAddress: Boulevard Manuel Avila Camacho Ignacio Zaragoza 2431

505906856.name: Playas sucias
505906856.author: a TripAdvisor user
505906856.reviewBody: Las playas del puerto de Veracruz nada recomendables sucias. Los desagues llegan a las plazas del Centro y la costera

address.streetAddress: Boulevard Manuel Avila Camacho Ignacio Zaragoza 2431

493587430.name: PLAYA TRANQUILA
493587430.author: a TripAdvisor user
493587430.reviewBody: Todo estuvo hermoso la playa tranquila, sin oleaje alto. muy suavecita la arena el problema son la gente de los restaurantes primero te dicen un precio y luego llega la cuenta y seg\u00fan son 100 pesos mas. comimos en el restaurante el tibur\u00f3n no se  los recomiendo. para no pelear los pague pero aguas ya saben que son muy abusivos en ese restaurante fonda.

address.streetAddress: Boulevard Manuel Avila Camacho Ignacio Zaragoza 2431

483230292.name: La playa limpia
483230292.author: a TripAdvisor user
483230292.reviewBody: El agua limpia y transparente. Lo malo muchos vendedores y la arena sucia por la falta de cultura de los visitantes.

address.streetAddress: Boulevard Manuel Avila Camacho Ignacio Zaragoza 2431

456755714.name: no es lo k esperaba
456755714.author: a TripAdvisor user
456755714.reviewBody: la verdad las playas de mexico no es lo que esperaba......\nsi tengo que decir que son limpias, pero no son pintorescas, el agua no es muy agradable.....es decir es mas bien algo fria. la arena en Veracruz no es esa arenita blanca y rica.... donde te encanta caminar descalza.\n

address.streetAddress: Boulevard Manuel Avila Camacho Ignacio Zaragoza 2431

649028063.name: Museo de la Ciudad
649028063.author: a TripAdvisor user
649028063.reviewBody: This museum seemed very basic. When we walked in, we were greeted and told that it was free. Upon entering the first room we were extremely fortunate to met Enrique Sanchez. He explained a little about the museum and informed us that he was a guide- if we wanted he could accompany us and explain a few things under no obligation. What a gem! Fantastic guide !! This was in Spanish and I would definitely recommend it. Honestly the museum and what one can take away isn\'t much compared to the information an experienced historian can give you. I\'m so glad he offered this and the knowledge we gained was priceless. Lots of old photos and an explanation of how the city was formed. There were some replica pieces and  also some  original pieces taken from nearby ruins and a giant fossilized turtle that is over 100 million years old. Incredible THANK YOU ENRIQUE!

601131804.name: Worth the visit but manage your expectations
601131804.author: a TripAdvisor user
601131804.reviewBody: Housed in a lovely, historic building in the center of town, this small museum is good but not great. It is also free. There is no gift shop or wifi and most exhibits are only in Spanish. The history of the fabulous city is well described.

582721697.name: Agree with some of the others
582721697.author: a TripAdvisor user
582721697.reviewBody: While it is not a great museum; it is a museum worth going to. It is so easy to find. You can walk from the cathedral easily. It was fun to walk through.

539143281.name: It is good to visit
539143281.author: a TripAdvisor user
539143281.reviewBody: In general it is interesting, good organised, but somehow it is limited. The history of Veracruz is really rich so I was expecting something more from this Museum. \nWhen the weather is too hot better to not visit this place - it is hot inside, no air conditioning.

497695431.name: Worth a visit.
497695431.author: a TripAdvisor user
497695431.reviewBody: Especially since it\'s free. If you have an interest in the history of the region and Mexico in genereal, you must visit. It helps if you speak Spanish but it\'s not required. Be prepared for the heat if you go during the hot months.

434767585.name: Small museum that provides solid information on the history of Veracruz
434767585.author: a TripAdvisor user
434767585.reviewBody:
While not a a world class museum, this museum should be a must see for anyone on their first trip to Veracruz.  The ground floor has several galleries that chronicle the nearly 500 year history of Veracruz.  The exhibits provide useful information, but are a bit in need of some refreshing, as they are looking somewhat worn.  Please be aware that all the information provided on the exhibits is in Spanish only.

The second floor is used for art classes and temporary exhibits, the exhibit on display when we were there in Oct. 2016 was interesting and worth a look at.

Admission to the museum is free.

375577989.name: Fabulosa!
375577989.author: a TripAdvisor user
375577989.reviewBody: Greatly enjoyed my visit to the museum in the company of guide Enrique Sanchez.  Next visit to Veracruz I will try to repeat the experience to absorb more.  Don\'t know if I can convince you but the history of Veracruz is enormously important not only in history of the Americas but also in the development of modern Europe. Not to be missed.

367535633.name: Beautiful building, great art
367535633.author: a TripAdvisor user
367535633.reviewBody: This is a small museum with a few English signs.  But the most amazing thing about it is the building itself and you don\'t need a translation.  There is a gorgeous domed ceiling with a mosaic of the sun.  The marbled stairs are stunning, though I wouldn\'t count on the hand rail!!  They were having an art exhibit upstairs that was absolutely stunning.  And, did I mention it was FREE.  Oh yes, it\'s free too.

365693087.name: Interesting view of old Veracruz.
365693087.author: a TripAdvisor user
365693087.reviewBody: Luckly for me, I was staying at Hotel Meson del Mar. The museum is barely a block away. I took the complete tour with a friend who does vacation tours. We ended up at the main office, spending nearly an hour talking about Veracruz with a State of Veracruz registered guide. I am a big fan of Veracruz and it was fun to learn some facts about Isla de Sacrifices and San juan de Uula.  Great visit.

359052086.name: Great Experience... If You Speak Spanish
359052086.author: a TripAdvisor user
359052086.reviewBody: I found myself in the unusual position of joining a group of students from the bachillerato (16-18 or so) on a guided tour of the museum.  The tour guide was informative and the museum was fascinating, but I\'m afraid it wouldn\'t have been very interesting if I didn\'t speak Spanish.  There were few (if any) signs in English and I\'m not sure if they do tours in English.

347353774.name: What a great day to learn the City
347353774.author: a TripAdvisor user
347353774.reviewBody: This is a time travel museum and I believe entrance is free.  Check it out to learn the development of the city.

344838775.name: a good overview of the history of the region
344838775.author: a TripAdvisor user
344838775.reviewBody: The museum is in a very nice hostorical building. There a artefact from the pre-columbian area and tne more recent history of Veracruz

319384252.name: Free and Very Informative
319384252.author: a TripAdvisor user
319384252.reviewBody: What a great place to visit for free. The exhibits are nice and the building is historic (was a hospital and then an orphanage and now a museum). The staff are very helpful with information about the building and things to do in Veracruz. And FREE is a great price!

257894504.name: good exposition, free
257894504.author: a TripAdvisor user
257894504.reviewBody: Covers the history of the city. Some exhibits are explained in French and English but many are only in Spanish. The enthusiasm of the guide compensates for my poor Spanish skills.

246492987.name: Awesome.
246492987.author: a TripAdvisor user
246492987.reviewBody: A great history of the area! With films, models, even archaological finds. Very thorough, and very regional. A very friendly guide gave a free tour. Stop in here first thing, it\'s a great intro. The best site in town.

245742435.name: Excellent museum run by a brilliant scholar
245742435.author: a TripAdvisor user
245742435.reviewBody: I used to live in Veracruz and I attended Toastmasters on Monday nights at this museum. The museum curator ran the Toastmasters and he was full of knowledge about the founding of the city. He spoke eloquently about topics from Augustin Lara to the Olmecs. He\'ll make time for you if you ask to speak to him. He is called Hector. The other staff is also friendly.\n\nAs I always say, if you see the artifacts, you\'re only getting a small portion of the story.

193685539.name: good museum for Veracruz
193685539.author: a TripAdvisor user
193685539.reviewBody: it was fun to learn a little about the history of Veracruz and the building it\'s housed in is pretty.

147240898.name: Check out the sidewalk
147240898.author: a TripAdvisor user
147240898.reviewBody: A presentation of pre-columbian and after the conquistidors. The sidwalk outside is a moseic of the history.

134228335.name: Nice Little History of the Region
134228335.author: a TripAdvisor user
134228335.reviewBody: Small but pleasant museum showing the overall history of Veracruz.

124774738.name: Veracruz history is here
124774738.author: a TripAdvisor user
124774738.reviewBody: If you visit Veracruz, this should be one of your stops to explore. A short walk from the Zocalo, you will be greeted by a very friendly and enthusiastic lady at the gates. She will not let you pass without signing her visitor\'s book and thorough coment on your visit as you leave. A one to two hour history lesson in spanish only, sometimes overlapping with similar information at the Naval museum. PS: the information sheet you receive at the tourist information center in City Hall is incorrect in regards to opening hours. The City Museum closes at 5 not at 6!

89691373.name: Good museum for an introduction to the history and culture of Veracruz
89691373.author: a TripAdvisor user
89691373.reviewBody: We were in Veracruz for a few days so why not take a look at the city museum. After all it was free too. Parts of the museum did focus on history of the city and surrounding area going way back to before the Spanish arrived. In addition, it showed loads of examples of the social and cultural history of the city, It included a few maps, artistic treats, and photos plus artifacts of bygone days. I don\'t think we were there for more than an hour but it was worth a visit to learn a bit more about this important city.
